awd_abstract_narration:
This award is to provide partial support for attendees of The 21st International Fibonacci Conference which will run from July 8th to 12th, 2024 at Harvey Mudd College in California. Fibonacci numbers in particular and recurrence relations in general arise in many areas. Thus there are many colleagues at all levels, from R1 institutions to teaching colleges to general scientists, working on problems in the field. The goal is to provide an inviting avenue for people to present their work and meet other interested parties. By bringing together a diverse group of researchers and practitioners we expect, as has happened in previous years, to have a productive meeting where several vantage points are provided to researchers to help suggest approaches and related problems; based on successes from previous conferences we expect many new collaborations to form. We have expanded topics from previous years to include applications in mathematical biology, music, and secondary education to excite the next generation of students. Run by the Fibonacci Association, many of the talks will be recorded and made publicly available, and papers related to the talks will be published as a conference proceedings as a special issue of the Fibonacci Quarterly.

With two sessions each day which can be attended in person or by zoom, speakers will discuss their work in 20 minute talks. Topics range from applications to $L$-functions to graph theory to combinatorial games to mathematics education to music to expanded predator-prey models in mathematical biology. There will also be 1-2 problem sessions where researchers will discuss both problems related to their talks as well as accessible topics for young researchers; the goal is to build research groups with senior personnel mentoring the large number of young mathematicians in attendance. For more information see:
https://21stinternationalfibonacciconference.wordpress.com/ .

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The support from the NSF was crucial in creating a successful, accessible conference. The funds were used to support the travel of numerous young mathematicians who had no funding otherwise, ranging from undergraduates to graduate students to postdocs and some colleagues outside academia but interested in returning. 

These participants gave numerous talks and papers based on their work will be published in a special conference proceedings issue of the Fibonacci Quarterly.

Several of the students supported have paid it forward and become mentors to the next set of students. Duties range from providing general advice to assisting the PI of the grant (Steven Miller) in running research projects (through the Williams College SMALL REU and the Polymath Jr REU).

Fibonacci numbers hold a unique spot in the mathematics community. Almost everyone has seen them from an early age, and there are numerous problems that are very easy to state in ways that a wide audience can understand. While frequently these problems have elementary (though not always easy!) solutions, oftentimes they serve as excellent springboards to introduce students to advanced techniques. Thus our goal in creating a conference such as this is not just to advance results on Fibonacci and related sequences, but also to help prepare students to work in a variety of allied fields. It is very valuable to have the funds to bring a large number of people together for several days to discuss mathematics; we deliberately scheduled the conference to encourage such interactions, from problem sessions to common housing (hotels and dorms).


Last Modified: 03/17/2025
Modified by: Steven J Miller
